elements.content: The structural properties of the iron mixed-valence complex (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] (dto = dithiooxalato, C2O2S2) have been investigated by single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) at low temperatures. (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] has two-dimensional (2D) honeycomb layers consisting of alternating FeII and FeIII arrays bonded by bis-bidentate dithiooxalato ligands. Upon cooling, a superlattice structure with q = (1/3, 1/3, 0) was observed below 260 K, which corresponds to an order–disorder transition of the (n-C3H7)4N+ ions between the honeycomb layers. The charge-transfer phase transition (CTPT) occurs at T C↑1/2 ∼ 120 K and T C↓1/2 ∼ 90 K upon heating and cooling, respectively, with an electron transfer between the FeII and FeIII ions, accompanied by a spin-state change, FeII (S = 2; HS)-O2C2S2-FeIII (S = 1/2; LS) ↔ FeIII (S = 5/2; HS)-O2C2S2-FeII (S = 0; LS). During the CTPT, the intersheet [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] distance decreased monotonously upon cooling, and an abrupt structural contraction was observed in the hexagonal 2D network. The volume contraction during the CTPT was quite small (∼0.7%), and differences in the structural distortions at the FeS6 and FeO6 sites were not found in the vicinity of the CTPT. We also calculated the orbital energies and the occupied spin states for the [Fe­(O2C2S2)3] and [Fe­(S2C2O2)3] octahedra in the vicinity of the CTPT by density functional theory (DFT). Because the local symmetry around the two coordinating iron ions is already lowered to trigonal symmetry, the CTPT did not cause any further deformation. This symmetry invariance resulted in an absence of orbital contributions to the total entropy change (ΔS) in the CTPT, which is in agreement with the previous heat capacity measurements. [Nakamoto, T; Miyazaki, Y; Itoi, M; Ono, Y; Kojima, N; Sorai, M. Heat Capacity of the Mixed-Valence Complex {[(n-C3H7)4N]­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3]}∞, Phase Transition because of Electron Transfer, and a Change in Spin-State of the Whole System. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2001, 40, 4716–4719.]

elements.content: The nature of order−disorder- and charge-transfer phase transitions (CTPT) of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] is revealed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements and DFT calculations. Because the local symmetry of FeO6 and FeS6 is already lowered to a trigonal one, the CTPT, where smooth one-electron transfer takes place between the d z 2 orbitals, did not cause any further deformation. The CTPT is mostly triggered by the differences in the phonon and the spin multiplicity between high-temperature- and low-temperature phases.
elements.clean_text: The nature of order-disorder- and charge-transfer phase transitions (CTPT) of (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] is revealed by single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements and DFT calculations. Because the local symmetry of FeO6 and FeS6 is already lowered to a trigonal one, the CTPT, where smooth one-electron transfer takes place between the d z 2  orbitals, did not cause any further deformation. The CTPT is mostly triggered by the differences in the phonon and the spin multiplicity between high-temperature- and low-temperature phases.

elements.content: Compared to pure inorganic materials, coordination polymers (CPs) offer advantages such as versatility in the design of their structural dimensionality, porosity, and chirality due to the diversity of coordination numbers and the geometries available with various combinations of metal ions and organic linkers. CPs have been extensively investigated for industrial applications in batteries, ion/gas storage, separation, catalysis, and so on. The flexible structures associated with their dimensionality have sometimes produced multiple functions, which can be controlled by external stimuli and by their crystal size to impart physical functionalities such as ferro-/ferrimagnetism, spin-crossover phenomena, electron/proton conductivity, ferroelectricity, and nonlinear optics, which have received substantial attention in recent years.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Compared to pure inorganic materials, coordination polymers (CPs) offer advantages such as versatility in the design of their structural dimensionality, porosity, and chirality due to the diversity of coordination numbers and the geometries available with various combinations of metal ions and organic linkers. CPs have been extensively investigated for industrial applications in batteries, ion/gas storage, separation, catalysis, and so on. The flexible structures associated with their dimensionality have sometimes produced multiple functions, which can be controlled by external stimuli and by their crystal size to impart physical functionalities such as ferro-/ferrimagnetism, spin-crossover phenomena, electron/proton conductivity, ferroelectricity, and nonlinear optics, which have received substantial attention in recent years.

elements.content: Charge-transfer induced spin transition (CTIST) is one attractive functionality in CPs, and it has been observed in heterometallic (e.g., M1–M2) and mixed-valence (e.g., MII–MIII) metal coordination systems. CTIST is a first-order phase transition between bistable spin states, which enables controllable magnetization by external stimuli. Cyanide-bridged polymers, such as Prussian blue analogues (PBAs), are representative materials that show CTIST, but CTIST has also been found in discrete complexes. Photoinduced CTIST has been reported in several heterometallic cyanide compounds; for example, K0.2Co1.4[Fe­(CN)6]·6.9H2O is the first photoswitchable magnet that can alternate between diamagnetic and paramagnetic spin states by excitation in the MMCT (metal-to-metal charge transfer) band. However, there are few reported examples of switchable magnetic properties based on thermally induced CTIST (often called the charge-transfer phase transition, CTPT, for mixed-valence systems) among mixed-valence CPs. To the best of our knowledge, no photoswitchable CTPT using photostimulation of the MMCT/IVCT (intervalence charge transfer) band has been reported in mixed-valence CPs. Actually, double-zigzag chain {[Fe­(Tp)­(CN)3]2­Fe­(bpe)·5H2O} n (Tp = hydrotris­(pyrazolyl)­borate; bpe = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane) is the first CTPT reported even among cyanide-bridged CPs but, again, is restricted to the thermal CTPT.
elements.clean_text: Charge-transfer induced spin transition (CTIST) is one attractive functionality in CPs, and it has been observed in heterometallic (e.g., M1-M2) and mixed-valence (e.g., MII-MIII) metal coordination systems. CTIST is a first-order phase transition between bistable spin states, which enables controllable magnetization by external stimuli. Cyanide-bridged polymers, such as Prussian blue analogues (PBAs), are representative materials that show CTIST, but CTIST has also been found in discrete complexes. Photoinduced CTIST has been reported in several heterometallic cyanide compounds; for example, K0.2Co1.4[Fe(CN)6]⋅6.9H2O is the first photoswitchable magnet that can alternate between diamagnetic and paramagnetic spin states by excitation in the MMCT (metal-to-metal charge transfer) band. However, there are few reported examples of switchable magnetic properties based on thermally induced CTIST (often called the charge-transfer phase transition, CTPT, for mixed-valence systems) among mixed-valence CPs. To the best of our knowledge, no photoswitchable CTPT using photostimulation of the MMCT/IVCT (intervalence charge transfer) band has been reported in mixed-valence CPs. Actually, double-zigzag chain {[Fe(Tp)(CN)3]2Fe(bpe)⋅5H2O} n  (Tp = hydrotris(pyrazolyl)borate; bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane) is the first CTPT reported even among cyanide-bridged CPs but, again, is restricted to the thermal CTPT.

elements.content: The iron mixed-valence compound (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] (dto = 1,2-dithiooxalato) is a unique system showing the CTPT with a thermal hysteresis of magnetic susceptibilities between T C↑1/2 ∼ 120 K and T C↓1/2 ∼ 90 K, as shown in Figure S1. This complex has a 2D (two-dimensional) honeycomb framework consisting of divalent and trivalent iron ions and bis-bidentate bridging dto ligands and has the same structure as bimetallic coordination polymer magnets, A­[MIIMIII(ox)3] (A = cation; MII = Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn; MIII = Cr, Fe, Ru, V, Mn; ox = oxalato). In contrast to oxalato-bridged complexes, dto analogues can incorporate different coordination environments; that is, the strength of the ligand field or the molecular-orbital levels can be tuned due to the asymmetry of the ligand. In (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3], the different spin states between the high- and low-temperature phases (HTP and LTP) result from an electron transfer between iron­(II) and iron­(III) ions as follows: HTP: Fe III ( S = 1 / 2 , LS ) − Fe II ( S = 2 , HS ) ↔ LTP: Fe II ( S = 0 , LS ) − Fe III ( S = 5 / 2 , HS ) One iron site, coordinated by six sulfur atoms, is always in the low-spin (LS) state, while the other site, with six oxygen atoms, is high-spin (HS) over the whole temperature range. Furthermore, the low-temperature phase undergoes long-range ferromagnetic ordering of the FeIII (S = 5/2) species, within a triangular lattice with ∼10 Å sides, through the diamagnetic FeII (S = 0) sites by a charge-transfer interaction. A previous heat capacity study suggested a small contribution to the entropy change of the CTPT from phonons, and the spin-entropy difference between HTP and LTP can be estimated as R ln­(10/6) = 4.25 J K–1 mol–1, representing a 46% total entropy change (ΔS = 9.20 J K–1 mol–1). Therefore, the phonon-based entropy contribution to the CTPT in the title compound is considered to be smaller than that observed in traditional spin-crossover phenomena, where it is ∼40 J K–1 mol–1. We have already reported the structural change at the CTPT by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). The unit cell volume change at the CTPT was very small at approximately 1%. However, the quality of the PXRD profiles for (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] synthesized by a one-pot reaction was not sufficient to clarify the structure at low temperatures by Rietveld analysis because the crystallinity of the powder sample was not high enough. Even though single-crystalline (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] could have been obtained, the structural aspects of the order–disorder transition of (n-C3H7)4N+ and the CTPT have not yet been completely clarified. Identifications of the average structure and FeS6 and FeO6 local geometries in (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] are of great significance for a systematic understanding of the CTPT and the related magnetism. Furthermore, the structural data help in understanding the spin-entropy driven CTPT.

elements.content: In this paper, we report single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) measurements of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] at low temperatures, where distortion parameters are introduced to the coordination geometries to express the structural transformations at the CTPT. Moreover, we performed density functional theory (DFT) calculations to elucidate the electron and spin configurations of mononuclear [Fe­(dto)3] moieties. From these combined SCXRD/DFT studies, we clarify the charge-transfer phase transition of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3].
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we report single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) measurements of (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] at low temperatures, where distortion parameters are introduced to the coordination geometries to express the structural transformations at the CTPT. Moreover, we performed density functional theory (DFT) calculations to elucidate the electron and spin configurations of mononuclear [Fe(dto)3] moieties. From these combined SCXRD/DFT studies, we clarify the charge-transfer phase transition of (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3].

elements.content: The single crystals of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] were prepared by a diffusion method using an H-type test tube. KBa­[FeIII(dto)3]·3H2O (0.32 g, 0.5 mmol) was placed at the bottom of one arm of the H-tube, and FeCl2·4H2O (0.10 g, 0.5 mmol), (n-C3H7)4NBr (0.26 g, 1.0 mmol), and ascorbic acid (0.2 g) were placed on the other bottom arm. Then, the H-tube was filled with a methanol/water (10:3) mixture. The preparation method used for KBa­[FeIII(dto)3]·3H2O is detailed elsewhere. Black needle-like single crystals with hexagonal prismatic habits grew at room temperature for one month in the dark. The obtained crystals were vacuumed up with the solvent and scattered on filter paper. They were washed well by methanol several times and then dried on the filter paper at room temperature for a few days.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

The single crystals of (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] were prepared by a diffusion method using an H-type test tube. KBa[FeIII(dto)3]⋅3H2O (0.32 g, 0.5 mmol) was placed at the bottom of one arm of the H-tube, and FeCl2⋅4H2O (0.10 g, 0.5 mmol), (n-C3H7)4NBr (0.26 g, 1.0 mmol), and ascorbic acid (0.2 g) were placed on the other bottom arm. Then, the H-tube was filled with a methanol/water (10:3) mixture. The preparation method used for KBa[FeIII(dto)3]⋅3H2O is detailed elsewhere. Black needle-like single crystals with hexagonal prismatic habits grew at room temperature for one month in the dark. The obtained crystals were vacuumed up with the solvent and scattered on filter paper. They were washed well by methanol several times and then dried on the filter paper at room temperature for a few days.

elements.content: The temperature dependences of lattice constants from 20 to 300 K were measured by SCXRD on a Weissenberg-type imaging plate (MAC SCIENCE DIP320V) equipped with a closed-cycle helium refrigerator (DAIKIN Co. V210CSG). For structural analysis at 88 and 140 K, a CCD SMART APEX (Bruker) was used with an OXFORD cold head blower to cool the sample directly. Monochromatic Mo Kα X-rays (λ = 0.71073 Å) were used in both apparatuses. The sample size was 0.239 × 0.169 × 0.114 mm3. Crystal structures were solved by a direct method (SIR2008 and SHELXS97) and refined on F 2 with full-matrix least-squares (SHELXL97 and SHELXL2017) using a CrystalStructure crystallographic software package (Rigaku).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Diffraction

The temperature dependences of lattice constants from 20 to 300 K were measured by SCXRD on a Weissenberg-type imaging plate (MAC SCIENCE DIP320V) equipped with a closed-cycle helium refrigerator (DAIKIN Co. V210CSG). For structural analysis at 88 and 140 K, a CCD SMART APEX (Bruker) was used with an OXFORD cold head blower to cool the sample directly. Monochromatic Mo Kα X-rays (λ = 0.71073 Å) were used in both apparatuses. The sample size was 0.239 × 0.169 × 0.114 mm3. Crystal structures were solved by a direct method (SIR2008 and SHELXS97) and refined on F 2 with full-matrix least-squares (SHELXL97 and SHELXL2017) using a CrystalStructure crystallographic software package (Rigaku).

elements.content: DFT calculations were carried out by Firefly version 8.1.1. The Kohn–Sham orbitals and d orbital splitting energies were calculated with the B3PW91 functional. The following basis sets were used: 6-31G­(d) for C and K, 6-31+G­(d) for O and S, and Stuttgart RSC 1997 ECP for Fe. Diffuse functions were omitted from the basis set of carbon atoms to improve convergence. The mononuclear complex models of K3Fe­(dto)3, with three potassium ions added to compensate for the excess charge, were derived from crystal structure data at 88 and 140 K.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

DFT calculations were carried out by Firefly version 8.1.1. The Kohn-Sham orbitals and d orbital splitting energies were calculated with the B3PW91 functional. The following basis sets were used: 6-31G(d) for C and K, 6-31+G(d) for O and S, and Stuttgart RSC 1997 ECP for Fe. Diffuse functions were omitted from the basis set of carbon atoms to improve convergence. The mononuclear complex models of K3Fe(dto)3, with three potassium ions added to compensate for the excess charge, were derived from crystal structure data at 88 and 140 K.

elements.content: The crystal structure of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] at room temperature has been already reported in a previous communication. An alternating array of FeIII and FeII ions joined through dto bridges forms a 2D honeycomb structure, and the 2D [FeIIFeIII(dto)3]− anion layers are stacked along the c axis via a (n-C3H7)4N+ cation layer (P63 space group). The nitrogen atom in each (n-C3H7)4N+ cation is located above the center of the hexagonal ring in the honeycomb layer, with one of the propyl chains penetrating the ring. The other three propyl chains are highly disordered within the ab plane with 3-fold symmetry.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussions

Temperature Dependence of Lattice Vibrations

The crystal structure of (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] at room temperature has been already reported in a previous communication. An alternating array of FeIII and FeII ions joined through dto bridges forms a 2D honeycomb structure, and the 2D [FeIIFeIII(dto)3]- anion layers are stacked along the c axis via a (n-C3H7)4N+ cation layer (P63 space group). The nitrogen atom in each (n-C3H7)4N+ cation is located above the center of the hexagonal ring in the honeycomb layer, with one of the propyl chains penetrating the ring. The other three propyl chains are highly disordered within the ab plane with 3-fold symmetry.

elements.content: An order–disorder transition for (n-C3H7)4N+ cations has been observed in the title compound as a broad peak in the heat capacity around T trs = 253.5 K. A similar order–disorder phase transition has been reported in (n-C4H9)4N­[MIIMIII(ox)3] (MII = Fe, Cu, Zn; MIII = Cr, Fe). A detailed heat capacity analysis suggested that a plausible model for the phase transition is a conformational disorder of the CH2 groups next to the terminal CH3 groups of the alkyl chains as gauche–trans-type kinking below T trs. For the (n-C4H9)4N­[MnIIFeIII(ox)3] compound, two different conformations of (n-C4H9)4N+, which are approximately in the ratio 2:1, have been reported by SCXRD measurement at 295 K. a,b shows the temperature dependence of the reflection intensities for selected satellite peaks, and fundamental reflections in the title compound, respectively. Below 260 K, satellite peaks appear, and their intensities increase as shown in a. Between 80 and 120 K, small changes are observed both in the satellite and normal reflection intensities during the CTPT. The gradient of the intensity vs temperature curves becomes gradual, and then, the intensities approach the saturation values below 120 K. c shows the diffraction image at 50 K. The weak satellite spots are located at 1/3 intervals of the distance between the hhl reflections, which are denoted as the indices of h/3 h/3 l (e.g., 4/3 4/3 5, 5/3 5/3 5, etc.). This finding indicates that the superlattice is built up with a periodic structure that is three times as long as the parent unit cell along the ab plane. The appearance of the superlattice corresponds to the order–disorder transition at approximately 253 K. Therefore, the thermal motions of the alkyl chains in the (n-C3H7)4N+ cations are likely to freeze gradually below 260 K, and the (n-C3H7)4N+ cations completely form a conformationally ordered array over the ab planes at low temperatures (d). The detailed structural conformation of (n-C3H7)4N+ is explained in the section. It should be noted that gauche–trans-type kinking of the NC2 group is found in (n-C3H7)4N+ cations, in which a gauche-type and two trans-type NC2 groups are superposed in three conformations of the propyl chain. (see ).

elements.content: The results of the SCXRD measurements performed at various temperatures are summarized in , which shows the temperature dependences of the a and c lattice parameters and the unit cell volume, V. The SCXRD data shows that the P63 space group of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] remains unchanged over the whole temperature range. clearly indicates that the anisotropic character of the unit cell parameters changes; that is, a thermal hysteresis loop due to the CTPT appears only in the a lattice value. Indeed, while the a parameter shows a discontinuous change in the vicinity of the CTPT, the c parameter exhibits a continuous variation with temperature, without the presence of a distinct change around ∼100 K. It is worth mentioning that the discontinuous change of a at T C↑1/2 ∼ 120 K upon heating is in good agreement with the critical temperature observed by magnetic susceptibility measurements and reported in Figure S1. The fundamental parameters of the natural thermal expansion for the a and c axes are expressed as a = Δ a 0 [ coth ⁡ h ν a 2 k B T − 1 ] + a 0 and c = Δ c 0 [ coth ⁡ h ν c 2 k B T − 1 ] + c 0 , where k B is the Boltzmann constant, h is Planck’s constant, and T is temperature. The thermal dependence of the unit cell volume is derived through the equation V = 3 2 a 2 c on the basis of a P63 space group. Here, a 0 and c 0 are the lattice parameters at 0 K. On the other hand, Δa 0 and Δc 0 are the scale factors expressing, in the high-temperature regime, the differences between the observed lattice parameters and the lattice parameters at 0 K, which are written (for a lattice parameter) as a ( T ) = a 0 + Δ a 0 × 2 k B T h ν a . The ν a and ν c are the Einstein frequencies of the solid. These values are obtained by least-squares fittings. The values of a 0, Δa 0, and hν a fit across the whole temperature range are 10.00 Å, 0.019 Å, and 83.5 cm–1, respectively. The corresponding Einstein temperature θ a = h ν k B (ν = 2ν a) is calculated as 120 K. The coefficient of linear expansion α a ( T ) = 1 a d a d T can be expressed from the previous formula, as α a , H T = 2 k B h ν a Δ a 0 a 0 in the high-temperature limit. The analysis of the curve in a gives α a = 3.24 × 10–5 K–1. Indeed, the lattice constant of a hardly shows any contraction in HTP and LTP. It should be noted that the coefficient of linear expansion for PBA compounds (having 3-dimensional structures) is approximately 10–5∼10–6 K–1, and the values fall within the same range in the vicinity of CTIST.
elements.clean_text: The results of the SCXRD measurements performed at various temperatures are summarized in , which shows the temperature dependences of the a and c lattice parameters and the unit cell volume, V. The SCXRD data shows that the P63 space group of (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] remains unchanged over the whole temperature range.  clearly indicates that the anisotropic character of the unit cell parameters changes; that is, a thermal hysteresis loop due to the CTPT appears only in the a lattice value. Indeed, while the a parameter shows a discontinuous change in the vicinity of the CTPT, the c parameter exhibits a continuous variation with temperature, without the presence of a distinct change around ~100 K. It is worth mentioning that the discontinuous change of a at T C↑1/2 ~ 120 K upon heating is in good agreement with the critical temperature observed by magnetic susceptibility measurements and reported in Figure S1. elements.content: Hence, the lattice contraction along the a axis is only observed upon cooling due to the electron transfer between FeII and FeIII in the 2D network. This change is only 0.5% of the a lattice parameter at room temperature, whereas for the c axis, the distances between the [FeIIFeIII (dto)3]− layers significantly decrease (∼2.5%) without any variance at the CTPT. The discontinuous change in the a lattice and the volume change at the CTPT are Δa ∼ 0.05 Å and ΔV ∼ 10 Å3, respectively. The value of ΔV is only 0.7% of the volume at room temperature, which is much smaller than that reported at CTIST for PBA compounds (7–10%). The obtained values of c 0, Δc 0, and hνc are 15.574 Å, 0.334 Å and 175 cm–1, respectively. The Einstein temperature of the lattice constant c is θc ∼ 251 K, and the coefficient of linear expansion of the c axis, α c , H T = 2 k B h ν c Δ c 0 c 0 is αc ∼ 1.71 × 10–4 K–1. Compared to the results of the analogous complex d 20-Ph4P­[FeIICrIII­(dto)3] with P63 symmetry, a = 10.101(2) Å, c = 18.001(4) Å (50 K), θa ∼ 220 K, and αa ∼ 3.73 × 10–5 K–1, θc ∼ 140 K, and αc ∼ 1.50 × 10–4 K–1, the values of thermal expansion along the a and c axes for the title complex are almost in same range as this reference compound, but the magnitude of the relationship of the Einstein temperatures, θa and θc , is reversed between the title compound and the reference compound. The thermal expansion of the a and c axes of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] is almost equal to that for d 20-Ph4P­[FeIICrIII­(dto)3], although the lattice vibration along the c axis in the title compound is substantially larger than that of the analogue compound, having a longer lattice constant, c (). The order–disorder transition of (n-C3H7)4N+ may correlate with the high Einstein temperature of 251 K in the c lattice through stronger interactions between the (n-C3H7)4N+ and [FeIIFeIII(dto)3]− layers, compared to the analogue compound.

To clarify the structural differences in the vicinity of the CTPT, SCXRD measurements on (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] were performed at 140 and 88 K along the cooling branch of the CT hysteresis loop. We applied a structural model, in which three moving types of the tetrapod-shaped (n-C3H7)4N+ cations are superposed on one countercation site, because (n-C3H7)4N+ is expected to have a precession-like motion along the c axis at high temperature (). Then, the three alkyl chains projected on a 3-fold axis, which align in a zigzag line in the ab plane, freeze below the order–disorder temperature (253 K), as their phase is adjusted every third period of the (110) plane. For the alkyl chain extended along the c direction and going into a [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] ring, the positions of the C atoms and terminating hydrogen atoms were calculated with 1/3 occupancy to prevent overlapping. Thermal vibrations for Fe, S, O, N, and C atoms were refined as anisotropic displacement parameters. The atomic positions and thermal factors at 140 and 88 K are listed in the CIF file. Crystallographic data and refinement conditions for the two temperatures are listed in .
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures at 140 and 88 K

To clarify the structural differences in the vicinity of the CTPT, SCXRD measurements on (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] were performed at 140 and 88 K along the cooling branch of the CT hysteresis loop. We applied a structural model, in which three moving types of the tetrapod-shaped (n-C3H7)4N+ cations are superposed on one countercation site, because (n-C3H7)4N+ is expected to have a precession-like motion along the c axis at high temperature (). Then, the three alkyl chains projected on a 3-fold axis, which align in a zigzag line in the ab plane, freeze below the order-disorder temperature (253 K), as their phase is adjusted every third period of the (110) plane. For the alkyl chain extended along the c direction and going into a [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] ring, the positions of the C atoms and terminating hydrogen atoms were calculated with 1/3 occupancy to prevent overlapping. Thermal vibrations for Fe, S, O, N, and C atoms were refined as anisotropic displacement parameters. The atomic positions and thermal factors at 140 and 88 K are listed in the CIF file. Crystallographic data and refinement conditions for the two temperatures are listed in .

Two independent Fe atoms, labeled Fe1 and Fe2, are located at the respective Wyckoff positions 2a and 2b on the 3-fold axis. The two independent O and S atoms of dto, labeled O1, O2 and S1, S2, are bonded to Fe atoms (). The chiral octahedra Λ-Fe­(dto)3 and Δ-Fe­(dto)3 are provided with 3-fold symmetry. In the present structural analysis, the racemic configurations of Λ-Fe­(S2C2O2)3 and Δ-Fe­(O2C2S2)3 provide 2D honeycomb sheets. The respective values of the Flack parameters at 140 and 88 K are −0.03(2) and −0.04(8).

elements.content: The lattice parameters and unit cell volume, V, of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] are a = 10.0764(9) Å, c = 15.779(2) Å, and V = 1387.4(2) Å3 at 140 K. Those values change to a = 10.0585(10) Å, c = 15.648(2) Å, and V = 1371.0(3) Å3 at 88 K. The lattice contraction of the a parameter from 140 to 88 K is ∼0.02 Å; therefore, the fraction of the LTP spin state (FeII (S = 0)–FeIII (S = 5/2)) at 88 K is estimated as ∼70% from the observed temperature-dependent lattice constants (a). It should also be noted that the abundance of the LTP spin state at 88 K is ∼60% according to magnetic susceptibility measurements on a powder sample (Figure S1), which is in good agreement with the present estimation. For the c axis, the nitrogen atom located at the center of the (n-C3H7)4N+ cation is over ∼5.1 Å from the Fe atom bonded to six oxygen atoms, and this distance represents 65% of the [FeIIFeIII(dto)3]− intersheet separation. This relative distance is comparable in HTP and LTP, and the ratio of the interlayer distance to the Fe–N+ distance is 7.89/5.12 (Å) at 140 K and 7.82/5.09 (Å) at 88 K, respectively (see b).

elements.content: For HTP and LTP, the coordination geometries around the Fe ions are identical within experimental error. The details are described below. The Fe–S bond lengths (Fe–S1 and Fe–S2) do not show much difference between FeIII–S (LS; S = 1/2) at 140 K and FeII–S (LS; S = 0) at 88 K. The change in the former is 2.288(6) Å to 2.289(6) Å, and that of the latter is 2.281(4) Å to 2.280(5) Å, respectively (see ). At 140 K, the angle formed by one dto ligand binding to Fe (S1–Fe–S2) is 89.75(13)°, and the straight angle formed from one vertex to another vertex of the octahedron, S1–Fe–S2, is 176.1(2)°. These respective angles at 88 K are 89.55(12)° and 176.13(14)°. In the FeO6 environment, the FeII–O bond lengths (Fe–O1 and Fe–O2) are 2.125(9) and 2.157(9) Å at 140 K, respectively, and the FeIII–O lengths become 2.123(7) and 2.154(6) Å at 88 K. The angles formed by the terminal O in dto-Fe and O1–Fe–O2 are 78.6(3)° and 169.9(4)° at 140 K, and 78.9(2)° and 170.3(3)° at 88 K, respectively.

The previous results indicate some deviation from octahedral symmetry (Oh ) for both FeS6 and FeO6 polyhedra. We thus introduce a degree of distortion as the smallest angle, α, between the vertices of the upper and lower triangles, which are formed by a 3-fold projection with each independent atom, O1 or S1 and O2 or S2 (a). Viewed along the c axis, the triangles pile up such as a hexagram when the twist angle, α, is 60° (Oh symmetry). The angle decreases with the degree of deformation; for example, α = 0 indicates that the octahedron changes to a trigonal prismatic (TP) geometry (D 3h ). Note that TP is reported in several compounds with interligand S–S or O–O bonds, such as bidentate trisdithiolane and tris­(catecholate) complexes. We also calculated the azimuthal angle, β, between the c axis and a line drawn between an Fe center and each independent S or O atom (b). The azimuthal angle, β = arccos 1 3 ∼ 54.74° is a perfect octahedron with Oh symmetry. When β is 60°, the symmetry of the crystal field becomes trigonal, making d z 2 the lowest orbital level. With this coordination, the sets of degenerate orbitals (d xz , d zx ) follow, then the d x 2–y 2 and d xy orbitals are at the highest energy according to crystal field theory. The twist angles for FeS6 in the title compound are α = 55.5° at 88 K and 55.5° at 140 K, while for FeO6, the values are α = 48.6° at 88 K and 48.2° at 140 K. Octahedra with shorter Fe–O bonds provide a more twisted shape than sulfur-bonded octahedra. Our structural analysis shows that the distortion degrees of FeS6 and FeO6 octahedra do not change in the vicinity of the CTPT. The respective averaged β values of FeS6 and FeO6 are 53.4° and 57.9° at 88 K, and 53.2° and 58.0° at 140 K. The averaged β angle values are almost unchanged above and below the CTPT.

elements.content: Obvious structural differences could not be found in the vicinity of the CTPT for (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3]. Crystallographically, FeS6 and FeO6 octahedra in [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] are slightly distorted to trigonal symmetry (D 3d ). According to ligand field theory, the T 2g orbitals in Oh symmetry are split into A 1g and Eg orbitals by the D 3d symmetry. With Oh symmetry, the entropy change in the CTPT (ΔS trans) contains contributions from phonons and spin and orbital degrees of freedom. The latter two, ΔS(orbital) = R ln 2 and ΔS(spin) = R ln[(5 × 2)/6)], where R is the gas constant, are summed up as ΔS trans = 10.01 JK–1 mol–1, which is already larger than the observed entropy change, ΔS CT = 9.20 JK–1 mol–1. However, the correlations between electrons on d orbitals and on ligand molecules, and structural deformations of the actual octahedra, have to be taken into account for the interpretation of CTPT entropy, since the conditions of orbital energy splitting and energy level interchange can substantially vary in the vicinity of CTPT. We carried out DFT calculations for the molecular orbital electron densities of Fe­(O2C2S2)3 and Fe­(S2C2O2)3 mononuclear structures based on the LT and HT crystal structure data determined at 88 and 140 K. The objective here is to investigate whether any orbital energy degeneracy is left and/or the energy levels are reversed as a function of the degree of distortion near the CTPT. When performing the DFT calculations, we used an approximate model in which K atoms were placed at the end of the dto ligands to neutralize the electron charge on Fe­(dto)3 induced by the imbalanced valences of Fe­(O2C2S2)3/Fe­(S2O2C2)3. The resultant Kohn–Sham orbitals were checked for the coefficients of the Fe d orbitals. The orbitals with d-coefficients larger than ca. 0.3 are considered to represent the spin distribution of the Fe ions. indicates the energy levels of occupied and unoccupied α-spin (up) and β-spin (down) orbitals at 88 and 140 K for Fe­(O2C2S2)3 and Fe­(S2C2O2)3. Detailed parameters are listed in . It should be noted that the z-direction is parallel to the axis of the K–dto propeller.

Obvious structural differences could not be found in the vicinity of the CTPT for (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3]. Crystallographically, FeS6 and FeO6 octahedra in [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] are slightly distorted to trigonal symmetry (D 3d ). According to ligand field theory, the T 2g  orbitals in Oh  symmetry are split into A 1g  and Eg  orbitals by the D 3d  symmetry. With Oh  symmetry, the entropy change in the CTPT (ΔS trans) contains contributions from phonons and spin and orbital degrees of freedom. The latter two, ΔS(orbital) = R ln 2 and ΔS(spin) = R ln[(5 × 2)/6)], where R is the gas constant, are summed up as ΔS  trans  = 10.01 JK-1 mol-1, which is already larger than the observed entropy change, ΔS CT = 9.20 JK-1 mol-1. However, the correlations between electrons on d orbitals and on ligand molecules, and structural deformations of the actual octahedra, have to be taken into account for the interpretation of CTPT entropy, since the conditions of orbital energy splitting and energy level interchange can substantially vary in the vicinity of CTPT. We carried out DFT calculations for the molecular orbital electron densities of Fe(O2C2S2)3 and Fe(S2C2O2)3 mononuclear structures based on the LT and HT crystal structure data determined at 88 and 140 K. The objective here is to investigate whether any orbital energy degeneracy is left and/or the energy levels are reversed as a function of the degree of distortion near the CTPT. When performing the DFT calculations, we used an approximate model in which K atoms were placed at the end of the dto ligands to neutralize the electron charge on Fe(dto)3 induced by the imbalanced valences of Fe(O2C2S2)3/Fe(S2O2C2)3. The resultant Kohn-Sham orbitals were checked for the coefficients of the Fe d orbitals. The orbitals with d-coefficients larger than ca. 0.3 are considered to represent the spin distribution of the Fe ions.  indicates the energy levels of occupied and unoccupied α-spin (up) and β-spin (down) orbitals at 88 and 140 K for Fe(O2C2S2)3 and Fe(S2C2O2)3. elements.content: At 140 K, in the HS state (S = 2) of FeII(O2C2S2)3, the energy difference (ΔE) between the A-symmetric α spin orbital (d z 2 ) and highest degenerate α orbitals (d xz and d yz ) is 1.99 eV, and the energy difference of d z 2 between the α- and β-spin orbitals is 2.39 eV. In the case of FeIII(S2C2O2)3, d z 2 is singly occupied, and the α and β orbitals of d x 2–y 2 and d xy , whose energy difference, ΔE, is 2.77 eV, are occupied, leading to a low-spin state (S = 1/2). The Mulliken spin populations (ρ s) on the FeII and FeIII atoms are ρ s = 3.78 and ρ s = 1.29. At 88 K, the d orbitals of FeIII atoms coordinated to oxygen atoms are occupied with all “up” spins, and energy levels of the d x 2–y 2 and d xy orbitals become higher than those of the d yz and d zx orbitals. d z 2 (α) gets closer to the d x 2–y 2 and d xy energy level (ΔE = 0.085 eV), and the energy difference, ΔE, between d x 2–y 2 –d xy and d yz –d xz is 1.34 eV. FeII(S2C2O2)3 possesses a diamagnetic state with occupied α and β orbitals of d z 2 and d x 2–y 2 –d xy , and ΔE = 2.637 eV. The spin populations on the FeII and FeIII ions are ρ s = 0 and ρ s = 4.19. The residual spin value (0.81) of the FeIII ions is distributed over the six oxygen atoms with spin values of ρ s = 0.098 (Fe–O1: bond length 2.123(7) Å) and ρ s = 0.105 (Fe–O2: bond length 2.154(6) Å). Electron delocalization could proceed at 88 K, and this kind of spin distribution cannot be observed at 140 K.

In the case of FeIII(S2C2O2)3, d z 2  is singly occupied, and the α and β orbitals of d x 2-y 2  and d  xy  , whose energy difference, ΔE, is 2.77 eV, are occupied, leading to a low-spin state (S = 1/2). The Mulliken spin populations (ρ s) on the FeII and FeIII atoms are ρ s = 3.78 and ρ s = 1.29. At 88 K, the d orbitals of FeIII atoms coordinated to oxygen atoms are occupied with all "up" spins, and energy levels of the d x 2-y 2  and d  xy   orbitals become higher than those of the d  yz   and d  zx   orbitals. d z 2  (α) gets closer to the d x 2-y 2  and d  xy   energy level (ΔE = 0.085 eV), and the energy difference, ΔE, between d x 2-y 2 -d  xy   and d  yz  -d  xz   is 1.34 eV. FeII(S2C2O2)3 possesses a diamagnetic state with occupied α and β orbitals of d z 2  and d x 2-y 2 -d  xy  , and ΔE = 2.637 eV. The spin populations on the FeII and FeIII ions are ρ s = 0 and ρ s = 4.19. The residual spin value (0.81) of the FeIII ions is distributed over the six oxygen atoms with spin values of ρ s = 0.098 (Fe-O1: bond length 2.123(7) Å) and ρ s = 0.105 (Fe-O2: bond length 2.154(6) Å). Electron delocalization could proceed at 88 K, and this kind of spin distribution cannot be observed at 140 K.

elements.content: Because the symmetry of the crystal field is already lowered in the HTP, the spin and charge redistribution does not cause a symmetry-breaking structural change. Therefore, a Jahn–Teller distortion cannot be observed at the CTPT. As a consequence, the entropy gained by the orbital angular momentum during the CTPT can be ignored. It is concluded that the observed entropy during the CTPT by a heat capacity measurement consists of two parts, spin entropy and lattice vibrations, the latter of which is small compared to usual spin-crossover (SCO) complexes or CTIST compounds.
elements.clean_text: Because the symmetry of the crystal field is already lowered in the HTP, the spin and charge redistribution does not cause a symmetry-breaking structural change. Therefore, a Jahn-Teller distortion cannot be observed at the CTPT. As a consequence, the entropy gained by the orbital angular momentum during the CTPT can be ignored. It is concluded that the observed entropy during the CTPT by a heat capacity measurement consists of two parts, spin entropy and lattice vibrations, the latter of which is small compared to usual spin-crossover (SCO) complexes or CTIST compounds.

elements.content: Since the phonon vibrations by the CTPT are exclusively observed in [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] sheets, the flexibility of the honeycomb network should strongly relate to the occurrence of the CTPT, rather than that of the Fe–dto and cation stacking layers, which mainly interact by van der Waals and electrostatic attractive forces. A report on the effect of chemical size using an anisotropic countercation, (n-C m H2m+1)3(n-C n H2n+1)­N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] (m, n = 2–6), indicated the criterion for honeycomb ring size for the CTPT to occur: the LTP appears by the CTPT when the a lattice size is below 10.2 ± 0.07 Å, while the shallow relation exists for the distances between the Fe–dto layers. The lattice flexibility index argued by the Einstein temperature has shown that the honeycomb network structure in the ab plane is softer than the [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] stacking layers along the c axis. However, from the results of the structural analysis near the CTPT, the structural change around each metal center is small, and the total lattice change in [FeIIFeIII­(dto)3] is also small. A possible reason for this observation is that the asymmetric ligand molecule, dto, has a large electron distribution of sulfur atoms, which promotes electron delocalization across the FeII-dto-FeIII linkage. Furthermore, the smooth electron transfer between FeS6 and FeO6 octahedra using one β spin on a d z 2 orbital (1 Ag ) causes the small structural change at the CTPT.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Change and Photoexcitation

Since the phonon vibrations by the CTPT are exclusively observed in [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] sheets, the flexibility of the honeycomb network should strongly relate to the occurrence of the CTPT, rather than that of the Fe-dto and cation stacking layers, which mainly interact by van der Waals and electrostatic attractive forces. A report on the effect of chemical size using an anisotropic countercation, (n-C m H2m+1)3(n-C n H2n+1)N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] (m, n = 2-6), indicated the criterion for honeycomb ring size for the CTPT to occur: the LTP appears by the CTPT when the a lattice size is below 10.2 ± 0.07 Å, while the shallow relation exists for the distances between the Fe-dto layers. The lattice flexibility index argued by the Einstein temperature has shown that the honeycomb network structure in the ab plane is softer than the [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] stacking layers along the c axis. However, from the results of the structural analysis near the CTPT, the structural change around each metal center is small, and the total lattice change in [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] is also small. A possible reason for this observation is that the asymmetric ligand molecule, dto, has a large electron distribution of sulfur atoms, which promotes electron delocalization across the FeII-dto-FeIII linkage. Furthermore, the smooth electron transfer between FeS6 and FeO6 octahedra using one β spin on a d z 2  orbital (1 Ag ) causes the small structural change at the CTPT.

elements.content: Here, we discuss the possibility of photoinduced the CTPT based on these structural aspects. The results of the photomagnetic measurements evidence the smooth electron transfer without large structural changes in the title compound. Figure S3 presents the evolution of the magnetic susceptibility under continuous light irradiation (532 nm) for a powder sample of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3]. The wavelength was selected from the temperature-dependent diffuse reflectance spectra (see Figure S2). Figure S2b depicts the temperature dependence of the Kubelka–Munk coefficient with 550 and 800 nm wavelengths of light, and shows a thermal hysteresis of the CTPT centered approximately 100 K with an ∼20 K width, which is in excellent agreement with the magnetic data in Figure S1. The magnetization curves after photoexcitation shown in Figure S3 overlap significantly with those measured in the dark, indicating that the CTPT photoexcited by continuous light irradiation is subtle at the specific wavelength of 532 nm, which may possibly induce LMCT. An additional narrow hysteresis loop appears between 10 and 50 K; however, the magnetization is not largely changed, such that only a slight spin-crossover phenomenon is induced by ligand isomerization at FeS x O6–x .

Figure S3 presents the evolution of the magnetic susceptibility under continuous light irradiation (532 nm) for a powder sample of (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3]. The wavelength was selected from the temperature-dependent diffuse reflectance spectra (see Figure S2). Figure S2b depicts the temperature dependence of the Kubelka-Munk coefficient with 550 and 800 nm wavelengths of light, and shows a thermal hysteresis of the CTPT centered approximately 100 K with an ~20 K width, which is in excellent agreement with the magnetic data in Figure S1. The magnetization curves after photoexcitation shown in Figure S3 overlap significantly with those measured in the dark, indicating that the CTPT photoexcited by continuous light irradiation is subtle at the specific wavelength of 532 nm, which may possibly induce LMCT. An additional narrow hysteresis loop appears between 10 and 50 K; however, the magnetization is not largely changed, such that only a slight spin-crossover phenomenon is induced by ligand isomerization at FeS  x  O6-x .

elements.content: In the phenomenological model of this two-level system, the lattice vibration terms and spin multiplicity (mainly for statistical population) are taken into account. The former determines the energy barrier, ΔE = E 1(x) – E 0(x), between the quadratic curves that depict the HT and LT states. In the title compound, it is likely that ΔE is not very high, and the quadratic curves for the HS and LS states strongly overlap due to small variations in the Fe–S and Fe–O bond lengths at the CTPT. In this case, the time scale of charge-transfer spin transitions accompanied by structural transformations is expected to be fast. The time differences between the electronic charge transfer (CT) and structural changes due to CT could not be observed due to the absence of strong elastic coupling that is usually generated by large volume changes in spin-crossover materials. As a result, it is difficult to obtain long lifetimes and stable trapping of the HS metastable state by thermal quenching and/or photoexcitation using continuous light irradiation. However, there is a possibility of photoexcitation using femtosecond laser excitations.

The former determines the energy barrier, ΔE = E 1(x) - E 0(x), between the quadratic curves that depict the HT and LT states. In the title compound, it is likely that ΔE is not very high, and the quadratic curves for the HS and LS states strongly overlap due to small variations in the Fe-S and Fe-O bond lengths at the CTPT. In this case, the time scale of charge-transfer spin transitions accompanied by structural transformations is expected to be fast. The time differences between the electronic charge transfer (CT) and structural changes due to CT could not be observed due to the absence of strong elastic coupling that is usually generated by large volume changes in spin-crossover materials. As a result, it is difficult to obtain long lifetimes and stable trapping of the HS metastable state by thermal quenching and/or photoexcitation using continuous light irradiation. However, there is a possibility of photoexcitation using femtosecond laser excitations.

elements.content: We performed a single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] at low temperatures. An order–disorder transition of (n-C3H7)4N+ was observed as a superlattice structure below approximately 250 K, which likely originates from gauche–trans-type kinking of the NC2 group of the propyl chains, which freeze in the [h/3 k/3 0] (h = k) direction. An anisotropic lattice contraction was observed in the temperature-dependent cell parameters during the charge-transfer phase transition (CTPT), with structural changes restricted to the [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] honeycomb network and to thermal hysteresis behavior. The noticeable structural contraction is in the a lattice parameter at the CTPT, while the interlayer distance decreases continuously with decreasing temperature. From the results of the structural analysis near the CTPT (120 and 88 K), and taking into account the precession-like motion of (n-C3H7)4N+, changes in the structural parameters, such as bond length and the buckling angle between the metal polyhedra in the [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] network, are also quite small at the CTPT when compared to the coordination polymers showing charge-transfer induced spin transitions, including Prussian blue analogues or spin-crossover materials. The DFT analysis revealed that the sets of d x 2–y 2 –d xy and d xz –d yz orbital pairs in the Fe atoms remain degenerate because the honeycomb structure maintains the same degree of D 3d distortion in the Fe­(S2C2O2)3 and Fe­(O2C2S2)3 octahedra throughout the CTPT. Since the electron transfer between FeS6 and FeO6 occurs smoothly, with one β spin in the d z 2 orbital (1 Ag ), the structural changes by the CTPT are considered to be small. Therefore, the orbital and angular momenta do not contribute to the total entropy change, ΔS trans, which decreases. As a result, the CTPT is mostly triggered by the differences in the phonon and the spin multiplicity between HTP and LTP.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We performed a single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis of (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] at low temperatures. An order-disorder transition of (n-C3H7)4N+ was observed as a superlattice structure below approximately 250 K, which likely originates from gauche-trans-type kinking of the NC2 group of the propyl chains, which freeze in the [h/3 k/3 0] (h = k) direction. An anisotropic lattice contraction was observed in the temperature-dependent cell parameters during the charge-transfer phase transition (CTPT), with structural changes restricted to the [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] honeycomb network and to thermal hysteresis behavior. The noticeable structural contraction is in the a lattice parameter at the CTPT, while the interlayer distance decreases continuously with decreasing temperature. From the results of the structural analysis near the CTPT (120 and 88 K), and taking into account the precession-like motion of (n-C3H7)4N+, changes in the structural parameters, such as bond length and the buckling angle between the metal polyhedra in the [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] network, are also quite small at the CTPT when compared to the coordination polymers showing charge-transfer induced spin transitions, including Prussian blue analogues or spin-crossover materials. The DFT analysis revealed that the sets of d x 2-y 2 -d  xy   and d  xz  -d  yz   orbital pairs in the Fe atoms remain degenerate because the honeycomb structure maintains the same degree of D 3d  distortion in the Fe(S2C2O2)3 and Fe(O2C2S2)3 octahedra throughout the CTPT. Since the electron transfer between FeS6 and FeO6 occurs smoothly, with one β spin in the d z 2  orbital (1 Ag ), the structural changes by the CTPT are considered to be small. Therefore, the orbital and angular momenta do not contribute to the total entropy change, ΔS trans, which decreases. As a result, the CTPT is mostly triggered by the differences in the phonon and the spin multiplicity between HTP and LTP.

elements.content: According to the reduced volume change accompanying the CTPT, the title compound has the potential to become a high-speed switching material because of its low vibronic energy, which arises from the weak coupling between the electronic and vibrational structures of this material. Furthermore, by taking advantage of the small structural changes at the CTPT and the structural porosity, [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] honeycomb networks with intrinsic FeII–FeIII oxido-reduction behavior could be proposed for applications as electrode materials in batteries, which require structural endurance during the charge–discharge processes by selecting the appropriate countercation. Thus, this 2D honeycomb frame built from asymmetrical ligands has the potential to achieve advanced functionalities and performances.
elements.clean_text: According to the reduced volume change accompanying the CTPT, the title compound has the potential to become a high-speed switching material because of its low vibronic energy, which arises from the weak coupling between the electronic and vibrational structures of this material. Furthermore, by taking advantage of the small structural changes at the CTPT and the structural porosity, [FeIIFeIII(dto)3] honeycomb networks with intrinsic FeII-FeIII oxido-reduction behavior could be proposed for applications as electrode materials in batteries, which require structural endurance during the charge-discharge processes by selecting the appropriate countercation. Thus, this 2D honeycomb frame built from asymmetrical ligands has the potential to achieve advanced functionalities and performances.

cln_elements.content: Temperature dependence of selected diffraction intensities of the (a) superlattice and (b) normal reflection spots. (c) (Left) Diffraction pattern of satellite spots reflecting a superlattice structure (marked with a triangle) and normal spots at 50 K. (Right) Optical microscopy image of single crystals of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII (dto)3]. (d) Schematic representation of the superlattice structure formed with the order–disorder transition of (n-C3H7)4N+ cations.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Temperature dependence of selected diffraction intensities of the (a) superlattice and (b) normal reflection spots. (c) (Left) Diffraction pattern of satellite spots reflecting a superlattice structure (marked with a triangle) and normal spots at 50 K. (Right) Optical microscopy image of single crystals of (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII (dto)3]. (d) Schematic representation of the superlattice structure formed with the order-disorder transition of (n-C3H7)4N+ cations.

cln_elements.content: Temperature dependences of the unit cell parameters (a) a and (b) c and (c) unit cell volume, V, for (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3]. Inset of part a shows the extended figure in the region of the charge-transfer phase transition (CTPT). Black lines and black dotted lines in part a and in the inset are inserted to guide the eye. The gray solid line in part a is the total fitting curve for all the data points. Black solid lines in parts b and c are fitting curves using all the data points based on the thermal expansion formulas.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Temperature dependences of the unit cell parameters (a) a and (b) c and (c) unit cell volume, V, for (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3]. Inset of part a shows the extended figure in the region of the charge-transfer phase transition (CTPT). Black lines and black dotted lines in part a and in the inset are inserted to guide the eye. The gray solid line in part a is the total fitting curve for all the data points. Black solid lines in parts b and c are fitting curves using all the data points based on the thermal expansion formulas.

cln_elements.content: Schematic representation of three (n-C3H7)4N+ cation geometries to account for precession-type disorder with C 3 rotation along the c axis in our structural model. The blue tetrahedron consists of the C31, C32, C33, and C6 atoms (gray spheres with an orange marker) linked with the N1 atom (blue sphere).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Schematic representation of three (n-C3H7)4N+ cation geometries to account for precession-type disorder with C 3 rotation along the c axis in our structural model. The blue tetrahedron consists of the C31, C32, C33, and C6 atoms (gray spheres with an orange marker) linked with the N1 atom (blue sphere).

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of (n-C3H7)4N­[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] at 88 K with thermal ellipsoids at the 50% probability level. Selected atoms in an asymmetric Fe–(C2O2S2)–Fe unit are labeled. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (a) Projection view onto the ab plane. Each conformational structure of the disordered cations is distinguished using white, pale aqua, and aqua colors. (b) Projection view onto the bc plane, where 2D honeycomb layers and cation layers alternate in stacks along the c axis by a second spiral axis. Only one conformation of the (n-C3H7)4N cations is drawn. The nearest neighboring Fe1···Fe2 distance and interatomic distance of Fe1···N1 at 88 K are indicated in the drawings. (The numerical values in parentheses correspond to the crystal structure at 140 K.)
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  Crystal structure of (n-C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] at 88 K with thermal ellipsoids at the 50% probability level. Selected atoms in an asymmetric Fe-(C2O2S2)-Fe unit are labeled. Hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity. (a) Projection view onto the ab plane. Each conformational structure of the disordered cations is distinguished using white, pale aqua, and aqua colors. (b) Projection view onto the bc plane, where 2D honeycomb layers and cation layers alternate in stacks along the c axis by a second spiral axis. Only one conformation of the (n-C3H7)4N cations is drawn. The nearest neighboring Fe1⋅⋅⋅Fe2 distance and interatomic distance of Fe1⋅⋅⋅N1 at 88 K are indicated in the drawings. (The numerical values in parentheses correspond to the crystal structure at 140 K.)

metadata.title: Structural Insight into Order–Disorder Transition and Charge-Transfer Phase Transition in an Iron Mixed-Valence Complex (n‑C3H7)4N[FeIIFeIII(dto)3] with a Two-Dimensional Honeycomb Network
